issue.title: Dynamic objects force each other into the ground.

content.raw:
I think the non-realistic inertia of the default cubes also plays a role here. For example, I tested this world with a "properly-inertialized"™ cube:

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="box">
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <inertial>
          <mass>10</mass>
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1.666</ixx>
            <iyy>1.666</iyy>
            <izz>1.666</izz>
          </inertia>
        </inertial>
        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <script>Gazebo/WoodPallet</script>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
~~~

Then:

1. Inserted a cube from the toolbar (the grey one)
1. Inserted two cameras
1. Waited for both cubes to auto disable
1. Paused simulation and placed each camera above each cube, but 100 m on Z
1. Pressed play, each camera dropped on a different cube
1. You can see that the grey cube slowly sinks while the white one doesn't

![dropcamera.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1282510287-dropcamera.gif)
content.html:
I think the non-realistic inertia of the default cubes also plays a role here. For example, I tested this world with a "properly-inertialized"™ cube:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="box">
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <inertial>
          <mass>10</mass>
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1.666</ixx>
            <iyy>1.666</iyy>
            <izz>1.666</izz>
          </inertia>
        </inertial>
        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <script>Gazebo/WoodPallet</script>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

Then:

  1. Inserted a cube from the toolbar (the grey one)
  2. Inserted two cameras
  3. Waited for both cubes to auto disable
  4. Paused simulation and placed each camera above each cube, but 100 m on Z
  5. Pressed play, each camera dropped on a different cube
  6. You can see that the grey cube slowly sinks while the white one doesn't
